item.title: Which InputStream should I use?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

LOL! i just found an obvious solution =P.

ok, use the ClassParser’s constructor that asks you for a file, but instead of just giving a file name (since it isn’t in the current directory), specify the whole path.

wow, i feel dumb. here’s an example if sum1 wana see: (it works, just change the File to a valid .class File path and it will print out all its methods)

import java.io.File;
import java.io.IOException;

import org.apache.bcel.classfile.ClassFormatException;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.ClassParser;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.JavaClass;
import org.apache.bcel.generic.ClassGen;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.Method;

public class InstructionFinder {
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		File f = new File("C:\\Documents and Settings\\Admin\\Desktop\\Tester.class"); //CHANGE TO VALID .class PATH
		if (f.exists()) {
			System.out.println("File exists!");
		} else {
			System.out.println("File doesn't exist");
		}
		JavaClass j = null;
		try {
			j = new ClassParser(f.toString()).parse(); //SEE THIS JUST USES A SPECIFIC PATH
		} catch (ClassFormatException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
			System.exit(0);
		} catch (IOException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
			System.exit(0);
		}
		ClassGen c = new ClassGen(j);
		Method[] m = c.getMethods();
		for (Method l: m) {
			System.out.println(l.toString());
		}
	}
}

Read full topic

item.title: Which InputStream should I use?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

This is what I believe you are thinking:

“I should provide a directory for the first parameter and a file for the second.”

This is what the documentation says:

“ClassParser(InputStream file, String file_name)”

Maybe you should try following it word for word i.e., new FileInputStream(new File(“C:\path\to\file\file.class”)), “file.class”

Read full topic

item.title: Which InputStream should I use?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:4, topic:283842”][quote author=Tenen link=topic=375124.msg2827402#msg2827402 date=1245125889]
Yes. I don’t see an InputStream that connects to a directory…
[/quote]
that wouldnt even make sense… you have to list the files in the directory, and open those files. (i assume that is your goal?)[/quote]nooo, let me explain… just to make sure we’re on the right path:

i am using bcel.

to do things to a class file we obtain a generic.ClassGen

to get a ClassGen we simply transform classfile.JavaClass by simply filling in the ClassGen constructor with the JavaClass

to get a JavaClass we use a classfile.ClassParser

ClassParser has three contructors. first obtaining a class from a zip (in the current directory), second obtaining a class from the current directory, and third obtaining a class from a InputStream.

since I have my class files in another directory, I’m going to have to use the InputStream constructor.

my problem is that I don’t know which type of InputStream to specify. (shown in my first post is code I tried, which failed.)

Read full topic

item.title: Which InputStream should I use?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

So, I’m making a BCEL updater. Right now, I’m trying to get a class from a different directory for ClassParser. ClassParser has only one constructor for this type of situation.

ClassParser(InputStream file, String file_name) Parse class from the given stream.
InputStream is an abstract class.

My question is what stream should I make? I’ve tried FileInputStream, but it failed. FileInputStream opens a stream to a File. A File (according to the API) is:

An abstract representation of file and directory pathnames.

So, File can represent a directory also.

Now, here is what I tried:

import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.FileNotFoundException;

public class InstructionFinder {
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		File f = new File("C:\\Documents and Settings\\Admin\\Desktop");
		if (f.exists()) {
			System.out.println("Directory exists!");
		} else {
			System.out.println("Directory doesn't exist");
		}
		try {
			FileInputStream fi = new FileInputStream(f);
		} catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
			System.out.println("Couldn't establish FileInputStream");
		}
	}
}

It’s output is:

Directory exists! Couldn't establish FileInputStream

I then thought that maybe a FileInputStream can only connect to a file, not a directory. If so, what stream should I use? If not so, why can’t it establish a stream?

Read full topic
